comments.commentBody: yes, she did it.  She could have decided not to pull the trigger.  Nine years old is not an infant.

It is my purpose, as one who lived and acted in these days, first to show how easily the tragedy of the Second World War could have been prevented; how the malice of the wicked was reinforced by the weakness of the virtuous. . . . We shall see how the counsels of prudence and restraint may become the prime agents of mortal danger; how the middle course adopted from desires for safety and a quiet life may be found to lead direct to the bull’s-eye of disaster.
Winston S Churchill
Surely you jest!

Pres. Obama has showed unbelievable strength in resisting the urge of the Right Wing to get tricked into hot wars in Syria and Eastern Europe. History will judge him favorably, undoubtedly as one of the greatest in the 21st Century.

What boggles my mind--after watching the President's presser--and listening to the follow-on from the commentariat raging about the U.S. inaction in either the Ukraine or Syria/Iraq--and the Twitter-fed fury fest that erupted after Obama acknowledged that the administration still does not have a strategy in terms of ISIS/in Syria--is that nobody disputes the validity of what the President said--just the fact that it fails to involve once again a demonstration of America's ability to blow someplace back to the Stone Age.

Correct me if I am wrong--but in my view, the President spoke the truth when he said that Russia and the US are NOT going to go to war over Ukraine--and that saying so did not come as some great revelation to Putin & Co.

Anymore then it would come as no surprise to the US or the Russians if the Russians merely blustered--but did not push the button on Armageddon--if we "intervened" in Central America in order to stop the invasion of minors that has preoccupied the limited thought capacity of press and punditry this summer.

Ukraine was a part of Russia for far longer than it was not--and the history of that land and people--for centuries---has been one of territorial conflict and empirical ambition since Biblical times.

The idea that the U.S. has an obligation to intervene--let alone a strategic interest to make that "right" is specious, hubristic nonsense.

Samantha Power called Russia exactly what it is--LIARS!!!!!  Yet Russia does not care; every sanction imposed on Russia has caused Russia to be even bolder.  As the US is setting the stage against Isis, President Obama quietly and thoughtfully is attempting to develop an international front against Russia and a Middle East Arab coalition against Isis.  The U.S. is a world leader but it is not the world.  The U.S. is the protector of the world but it cannot involve itself in every backyard skirmish.  The U.S. can assist and prod other nations to take greater responsibility in their defense and battle imminent threats affecting them directly. In the world there are many and the U.S. is one; responsibility of self defense falls upon individual nations not primarily on the U.S. The president focus is to have nation be self-reliant and not to dependent on America’s military; after 13 years of war, Americans are not too eager to re-engage!

Even if Obama does not want to get militarily involved, does he have to publicize this information? Why does he want to keep his enemies so well informed? One of the important Chinese military strategies is 'Know your enemies, but not let them know about you'. It seems that Obama cannot strategize and his strategy is to 'wait and avoid' until everything falls apart and all opportunities lost.
It is my sincere desire that we, as a country, facing these international crisis can be united in addressing them and put away selfish bipartisan politics, although I'm not hopeful.
I am grateful for president who says what he thinks, acknowledges gray areas and doesn't always fasten on war first.

I am not sure why everyone is blaming Obama. I never voted for him but I agree with his non interventionist policies. This is a German problem. Germany is unwilling to even consider serious sanctions. There is nothing the US can do alone. If Europe leads, US can support. This is a fair and square a European problem.
When the ostrich pops up from the hole, it may very well be missing its' head.

Mr. Appledorf, you could not be more wrong about the availability of a ready diplomatic solution in greater autonomy for Eastern Ukraine. Ukraine's Poroshenko was taking just such a proposal to Putin at the very moment that Putin was sending more Russian armored columns into Ukraine. Furthermore, although Eastern Ukraine has wanted more autonomy, they want even more not to leave Ukraine to join a new Russian orbit. Only a relatively small minority of Eastern Ukrainians and Putin's Russia support the separatists.

The real problem is that Putin has much greater ambitions for Ukraine than even "liberating" Eastern Ukrainian separatists from the rest of Ukraine, and he rather poorly hides those ambitions with constant lies about his actions and intentions. The man is a sociopath of the highest order and cannot be negotiated with on a rational basis.

Frankly, the only diplomatic pressure that will work with Putin is that which actually makes Putin's life more miserable without causing him to launch another World War (which could be our last). What makes Putin even more dangerous is that it is extremely difficult to know just how miserable we can make Putin's life without him doing something that triggers a wider conflict.

Basically, if not for Putin, Ukraine would sort out its own problems just fine.

Sorry, I must have missed the head fake, I was too taken with his summer attire to be paying close attention to which way his head was moving.

And calm down Tim, the last thing I'd want to see Obama do is some Rambo-like thing and threaten to push the launch button. But does he really have to answer every question the press asks with such candid honesty? Sometimes silence is more deafening than thunder.

Yes, unfortunately, it must be music to Putin's ears that his own bet that the world will not dare to militarily engage the world's second-greatest nuclear power is paying off beautifully.  However, the fact is, we really cannot risk a world war with Russia for obvious reasons: it would be the shortest and last world war humanity might ever fight.  So, painful pressure must be applied to Putin, but it cannot be so painful that nuclear tipped ICBMs start flying around the world.
I would gladly fight and die for my country.  In the grand scheme of things our lives are over in the blink of an eye anyway, and i can think of worse ways to go than defending my country.

It is disappointing to see Mr Obama use weasel words to describe what is surely an invasion-perhaps a creeping one-but an invasion. Even Russian media sources are calling it a"war" By minimizing this invasion he is again playing the Putin game. While a European war is the last thing anyone wants- now is the time for US and EU to strike hard at Russia on the diplomatic and economic front. The past sanctions have not made much difference-more of an inconvenience to some shoppers. Mr Obama and his colleagues must now-not next month-take drastic measures against Russia. He can start by not issuing visas to any Russian citizen for travel to America. Russian banks can be sanctioned further so that interchange with European banks is virtually brought to a standstill. These actions, with others, should cause a drop in value of the Russian Ruble-further increasing the cost of Putin's war.
Western countries must signal deep displeasure now. Words are not sufficient. This is one time Mr Obama must act-not just ruminate. He and US ambassador to UN have accused Russia of supplying arms and bodies in the Eastern Ukrainian struggle and have called the Russian diplomatic core liars. What else does it take-short of a march on Kiev-to make this Putin adventure very costly for Russia. Already, Russian media are questioning the secret burial of Russian soldiers. Many Russians remember the body bags coming home during the Afghan debacle.

In any case, part of inflicting sufficient diplomatic pain on Putin may well mean that we suffer some domestic pain as a result.  No doubt, Putin's sociopathy would not mind if the world economy crashed along with that of Russia's.  However, it may be the only way to get Russia to wake up, take down Putin, and take up a more productive course in the world.  It is incredibly unfair for innocents to suffer because of an evil despot like Putin, but that is already happening, and it will only get worse.  The question is, will that worsening effect lead to a more productive result by forcing Putin's fall than by allowing him to keep blackmailing Europe and even the U.S., not to say much of the rest of the world.

Bruce, we do have a friend in the Middle East, Israel.An ally that our President has given strong support as have the American people.Keep Israel strong through military aid.Keep the Homeland safe by whatever means necessary and let the Islamic gangsters kill each other.Let Russia and Ukraine have each other.
War with Russia is unthinkable.

It is not clear that Putin wants Ukraine. He does want the Russian speaking areas of Ukraine. There is no reason for him to occupy west Ukraine where he is unpopular and people have his picture inside urinals.

Putin may be tough but there is no reason to think he is a fool.
Good cop/bad cop? Good! It's a popular approach because it works.

The mixed messages between Samantha Powers and the President are a classic display of "good cop bad cop". One threatens while one consoles. This is primarily a stalling tactic to make us look tough while we consider how to act tough, if we are ever are going to act tough.

As bad as the Russian invasion is, there is no way the West and the US in particular are going to risk a shooting war with Russia. Ukraine simply isn't worth it. Putin knows that. He knows we would never let him march his armies into Poland, but Ukraine, that's his backyard. I'm not justifying Putin's aggression, just explaining it. In this world, people will do pretty much whatever they think they can get away with.

ISIS is another matter. Any decent person would want to crush those murderers immediately. As I commented this morning, we can't even determine who our friends are in the middle east. In fact, we can't determine who anyones's friends are over there. Its easier just to consider them all enemies. I will give the President the benefit of the doubt that he is weighing how our potential killing can be directed to minimize future killing. This may be a foolish choice as the future killing will happen anyway. It may be best to clobber ISIS now and not be concerned about the aftermath because we wont be able to influence it. Stopping them from their barbaric rampage maybe all that we can reasonably do. Whatever happens after, happens. I don't envy the President's predicament.

And what triumph would you attribute to American foreign policy in the last 50 years? China? North Korea? Iran? Iraq? Viet Nam? How about Libya? I'm not talking about recent events in Libya, I'm talking about the time they blew up an American jet. How was the response then? Essentially, American governments of every stripe have been remarkably ineffective in foreign affairs, although the rhetoric certainly flies round in circles. The problem with our current policy is not this president, its this economy. We've allowed ourselves to become financially weak. Without the strength of the dollar, we have never had any strength beyond a arrogant posture. And at a time when we need a strong central government, we're victimized by rank amateurs with no vision of what government is at all, and what we need it to be.
And well he should, since it happens to be true.
Obama/Powers could be something of a "good cop/bad cop" scenario. I'm sure President Obama knew and approved Samantha Powers message before it was delivered.
or perhaps he is not showing his hand.
What makes you think she was innocent? She pulled the trigger.

"The Boomer generation and their parents need to start composing their apologies to future generations. Because they're responsible."

You obviously haven't heard of "history", while some of the "baby-boomers" were conservative the majority were more liberal than you'll ever be. Besides being opposed to the war in Viet Nam the boomers also embraced civil rights (ie. I don't care what color your skin is), sexual rights (ie. the pursuit of happiness) along with the Equal Rights Amendment.

The bulk of the "boomers" are liberals and quite proud of it, if you want to "dis" them for being "liberal" that's fine but to say they weren't liberal shows nothing be a disconnect with reality. Much that exists today wouldn't exist if it hadn't been for the boomers. Civil rights, gay rights, women's rights were all embraced by the boomers, they wouldn't be in today's vocabulary otherwise.

You had me there until the end. Blaming a certain age group for all of humanity's problems is weak.

Also, the oldest 'boomers' are nearing 70, and in most cases, their parents are long dead.

Oh, you can bet I've heard of history. And anybody that claims "the bulk of the 'boomers' are liberals" hasn't been paying attention. It was the "boomers" responsible for Reagan/Thatcher and their bared teeth political descendants. It was the people who, in their idealistic youth, were going to "change the world" who then went and elected the conservatives who promptly deregulated the financial system, ignored global warming and climate scientists, accepted "free" trade for the investor class, embraced supply-side economics and spread its nonsense around the world, ..., I don't need to go on. And it was the cowardly liberals who sit back and allowed themselves to be self-servingly co-opted or corrupted and remained mum during the whole thing.

Start writing your apologies. The future will hate you, whether you're an ignorant conservative or a milquetoast liberal.

America teaches the world. The cowardice of left-leaning politicians is international, and they are the planet's only hope. It is crushingly depressing to fathom that the ideas of the Enlightenment resulting in liberal democracies/republics may have -- even more then Communism -- overestimated the ability of humans to govern themselves. The status of the Middle East and rise of fundamentalism there and the totalitarian authoritarianism tendencies of significant factions of Christianity in America add to the depression.

The Boomer generation and their parents need to start composing their apologies to future generations. Because they're responsible.

The so-called problem of pass-through entities is the result of our effort to tax the same income twice when earned by non pass-through businesses:  once to the business entity and again when distributed to the owners of the entity.  We should either accept the principle of "tax income only once" or apply double taxation to all business income, regardless of the structure through which it is earned.

There's no doubt the tax code (the WHOLE tax code and not just the corporate tax code) needs to be revised.  However, until a comprehensive study also looks at how that passed-through income is taxed on the individual level, we are not seeing the whole picture.   Inversions are one thing (and arbitrage differential treatments amongst jurisdictions); but your other examples neglect to mention that that income is taxed, and perhaps at a higher level (39 percent federal, plus local taxes) than the 35 percent corporate rate.   Not to mention the earnings and capital appreciation captured with estate taxes.
